snippet: Chad Hooks, 23, spent three years, seven months and three days at Rikers Island before his trial on charges of killing a man finally got under way in the Bronx. The family of the victim had to wait, too.
abstract: Bronx has about 60 percent of New York City's oldest pending felony cases; average wait for trial in borough is more than one year, much longer than state's 'speedy trial' guidelines; backlog is illustrated by plight of Chad Hooks, who spent three years, seven months and three days at Rikers Island before his trial got underway (Series: Justice Denied).

byline.contributor: Robbie Brown, Alain Delaquérière and Colin Moynihan contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Chad Hooks, 23, spent three years, seven months and three days at Rikers Island before his trial on charges of killing a man finally got under way in the Bronx. The family of the victim had to wait, too.

headline.seo: After a Killing in the Bronx, a Sentence to Wait
headline.main: For 3 Years After Killing, Evidence Fades as a Suspect Sits in Jail
